blocks.text: SELECT queries are the foundation of SQL. They allow you to retrieve specific data from one or more tables in a database.

list: SELECT * FROM table_name – retrieves all columns
SELECT column1, column2 – retrieves specific columns
WHERE clause – filter rows based on conditions
ORDER BY – sort results ascending or descending
LIMIT / OFFSET – control the number of rows returned

code.content: SELECT name, email FROM Users WHERE status = 'active' ORDER BY name ASC LIMIT 10;

blocks.text: Now, to make it more real-world, imagine a company with thousands of users and millions of transactions. Efficient SELECT queries allow managers to get insights quickly.

blocks.title: Pro Tip
blocks.text: Always select only the columns you need. Using SELECT * may impact performance in large tables.

list: Using functions in SELECT: CONCAT(), LENGTH(), UPPER(), LOWER()
Using subqueries: SELECT * FROM Orders WHERE user_id IN (SELECT id FROM Users WHERE status='active')
Combining results with UNION or UNION ALL

blocks.text: Mini Exercise: Retrieve the top 5 users with the highest order amounts, but exclude inactive users. Think about which clauses you would use (WHERE, ORDER BY, LIMIT).
Explanation for beginners: Every SQL query has three phases: Parsing → Optimization → Execution. Understanding this helps in writing efficient queries, especially in large-scale systems.
We can also use JOINs within SELECT queries to combine data from multiple tables. We'll cover JOINs in the next subtopic.
